At the film‚Äôs outset, Michael is an outsider to the family business‚Äîa decorated war hero, a university man, a figure of apparent virtue and detachment. Simply put, The Godfather is perfect. No film, except it's sequel, has come close to the level of cinematic nirvana that Coppola's work achieves. The performances, the direction, the writing, Gordon Willis' cinematography, the story, the set-pieces, the tension, the dynamics, the layers; It all culminates in a work that is as essential and as influential some of the great works of literature. Simultaneously a mafia and a family story, The Godfather isn't just focused on the inner workings of organized crime. Rather, Francis Ford Coppola's masterpiece shines its voyeuristic lens on turmoil, family bonding, tragedy, betrayal, love, fate, power, and the crumbling of society. All of these themes and motifs are set against a changing landscape of 1940s Americana, elaborating on a shift in ideals that brings both disillusion and heartbreak. I cannot wax poetic enough when it comes to this movie. It was one of the first that made me realize how editing, direction, and cinematography come together to tell a story. In particular, the meeting between Michael and Sollozzo blew my mind at the tender age of 9, and I've been addicted to these types of stories ever since. There's something about an organized story that translates so well to a great drama, and It all has something to do with the themes. The story in The Godfather is as dense and as classical as the works of Shakespeare, and this is one of the few films that deserve to be called 'Spakespearean.' Even though my love for this film is limitless, It's hard for me to write about it. There's been essays, papers, and entire books dedicated to this gold-mine of a cinematic work, and while I would love to write a long piece on it, I don't have the words just yet. This isn't even my favorite Godfather film, but the fact that It's still in my top 15 of all time says so much about Coppola's filmography in the 1970s. Epic in scope while maintaining a patience and intimacy characteristic of European art cinema, the Godfather is rightly considered one of the greatest films ever made. It continues to influence producers of films, television shows, and video games more than 40 years after its release. Nino Rota's score, the set design, and Brando's raspy pseudo-whisper have become part of our collective cultural memory. The film possesses an operatic quality, yet it's more understated than it is flamboyant. It takes its subjects seriously, bestowing legitimacy upon the internecine power struggles of the Mafia normally reserved for classical themes in high art. The film's release initiated a period when American filmmakers dared to take themselves and their artistic ambitions seriously. There's something deeply resonant in the film's treatment of filial piety, the need for respect, and our culture's abiding interest in the parallel moral universe of the Mafia.

What makes a movie great? How can a movie be considered the best of the best? These critical questions have been asked for decades, but is there really a clear answer? "The Godfather" (1972), directed by Francis Ford Coppola, has been considered one of, if not, the greatest movie ever created, and more than 25 awards and 3 Oscars seem to back this claim. However, is this really the case? Is this adaptation of Mario Puzo's "The Godfather" novel truly the best of the best? I'll put it simply: yes. This movie is the epitome of what a movie should look like and deserves all of the recognition it has received over the years. One of the many reasons that Francis Coppola's "The Godfather" is considered a cinematic masterpiece is that it kickstarted an entirely new generation of films. Albeit many mobster and crime films forego the creation of "The Godfather", Coppola soaked his film in foreign, Italian culture and depicted these gangsters as extremely intelligent and capable people with extensive mental profundity. As a viewer, you are immediately drawn towards the puissant character of Don Corleone, brought to life from an incredible performance by Marlon Brando. From his first few minutes on-screen, his powerful presence is felt through to audiences everywhere. Brando's peaceful, downplayed execution as the Don is one of the components of this film that makes it extremely enjoyable to watch and sets it above all others. That being said, it is critical to recognize the further incredible performances given throughout the film. Al Pacino's presentation of the intelligent and innocent son of Don Corleone, Michael, is nothing to be looked over. Michael's agonizing earnestness could only truly be performed by Pacino. Furthermore, James Caan, Robert Duvall, Richard Conte, and Diane Keaton, among many others, give sincere, gripping performances that would make any viewer feel for each and every character. Relatively few motion pictures can be 3 hours long but keep a decent degree of interest from the crowd like "The Godfather". The messages and themes throughout the film aren't simply credited to the directing or the cast, but also to the overall production. The film is so well put together as a whole that it is extremely difficult to dissect the movie and point out its flaws. After my first watch, I nearly created a petition to change the definition of the word "perfect" to something else: "The Godfather". It is utterly impossible to glance past and ignore the beautiful cinematography put together by the legendary Gordon Willis and the incredible score produced by the acclaimed composer Nino Rota. To summarize my experience, I truly believe "The Godfather" has this uniqueness and almost imaginary feel that gives the viewer the inclination that they are watching the greatest film ever brought to cinema. One simply cannot live a life without experiencing this masterpiece.

The Godfather is an American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola, who co-wrote the screenplay with Mario Puzo and it was released in 1972. The film is based on the novel with the same name which was written also by Puzo. It stars actors such as Marlon Brando who plays the godfather as Vito Calderon in the film and also Al Pacino who plays as his youngest son Michael. This film is regarded as one of the best films ever made and it has influenced the mafia genre quite a lot. I have to agree and say this film was very impressive and not in the way that I expected. The film is about a crime family in New York who is led by Vito Corleone it is set in the 40s and 50s and it starts at the wedding of Vito Corleone's daughter but we are in Vito's office where he is doing his business. This scene is a very good example of how the film separates the life-and-death contrast; while outside there is a very bright and happy wedding this room is very deep-toned, shuttered, lighted by lamp even in the day time, and the story moves back and forth between this hidden world and the sunshine that is outside. This back and forth however might be bit off putting at first to follow the story, but it makes separation between those two worlds a lot more real. You get the sense that this underworld darkness is another secret life with its own fear, more real than the sunlight world outside. If we talk about the story a bit more at this business meeting Johnny Fontane, a popular singer and Vito's godson asks him if he can help Johnny secure A movie role. This is the first time we see the crime family in action. Bit later and shortly before Christmas, drug lord Sollozzo, backed by Tattaglia crime family, ask Vito for investment and protection through his political connections which Vito declines this leads to Vito getting attacked by de Tattaglia family which forces his youngest son Michael to take over the family business. This leads us to what I think is one the films strongest points which is its characters. Of course, we start with our main man Marlon Brando as Don Vito Corleone, the godfather' of a powerful Sicilian- American family and it was acted beautifully with his rasp voice, twisted mouth he is very seductive when he talks and even if it wasn't told its very believable. Yes he is this dark powerful king of the underworld. Brando isn't the whole show Michael who was played by Al Pacino manages to change from a small, fresh-faced, handsome college boy into an underworld lord, becoming more intense and more isolated at every step. In conclusion the things that I like about this film are, first of all the story and the thing I like about it is that story is told from the inside the crime family .We see things not black and white or good or bad but a lot more deeply. Secondly is the characters especially their development and Michael is a prime example the way he transforms from being an innocent outsider to his family and their business to being their head and following his father footsteps even when he didn't want it. Also, I found the cinematography quite impressive as I said in the beginning the way darkness represents the crime world is great you can see this very visible with Michael the way his face fades it to the shadows as he gets in to the family business shows a change in a character very well. I think this is a great film it might not be revolutionary as it was 50 years ago but is still if you haven't watched it strongly suggest you should give it to try.

The Godfather is a true masterpiece. Everything in the filmmaking- cinematography, story, dialogue, acting, directing- is pitch perfect and feels way ahead of it's time. It is a true trendsetter- countless gangster films in the decades following have been trying to do what it did so well, and none with such fantastic results. Don't mistake this for a fun, popcorn, blockbuster however. I look at it as a sort of cautionary tale- an honest look at how nasty a life in organized crime can become. The action and violence is never glamorized, and it isn't making light of the heavy themes. You don't realize it until somewhere around the halfway point- but the central character is Michael Corleone. Michael starts out as the bright light of the family- he has had no involvement with the "family business", and is a decorated WWII veteran. Michael initially gets his hands dirty when he is trying to protect his father. He makes a choice to kill those who intend to kill his father. Despite that Michael has likely killed before in military combat- something is different about these killings. After sinking his hands into the filth, he must spend an extended holiday in Italy to evade the law. During this time he is given a second chance- he falls in love, gets married, and seems to find happiness. But this can only be temporary- he is still a wanted man, a member of a well known crime family, and the violence that he unleashed only leads to more violence.

The most appropiate definition of "Materpiece". Tell me a movie that is more famous than this. Tell me a movie that has had more parodies spinned off its storyline than this. Tell me one movie that has been as quoted as a much as this. The answer is you can't. No movie has had as much of an impact as The Godfather has had ever since it was released. The acting was simply amazing, what else could you say. What could be more appealing to people(even today) than watching actors like Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, James Caan, Diane Keaton, Talia Shire and Robert Duvall. This is like heaven for someone who is a fan of movies. With this movie Brando was able to bring himself back into the limelight. His performance as the godfather alone is iconic. His character has been recreated so much in films that it has almost if it has not already become a clich√©. His performance though was not a clich√©. His performance was subtle and breathtaking. It was so genuine and realistic that it was not just probably but definitely more genuine than Marlon Brando himself. Al Pacino was perfect for this film as well. What a way to start up your career. His character was all about depth and he displayed it perfectly. He was able to display his own inner-battles in his mind as well as the battles he had with his family, friends and enemies. His character was more of a psychological character study than anything else to me. Robert Duvall to me was the glue to the movie. He added a different perspective to everything in just that he was not Italian yet having the respect of the mafia. His character is a man of high authority within the Corleone family who was listened to and insightful;. This was simply perfect giving the film great balance throughout. The rest of the cast was just icing on the cake. The writing was phenomenal and breathtaking. As mentioned before there has been no movie quoted more than this. It is not even the quotes though that makes the writing in here so perfect. It is the symbolism and meaning that went into every scene. There are countless symbols, messages and lines in here that are so memorable yet it is as realistic as a movie could get. The directing by Coppola was perfect as well. Not many movies can be 3 hours and yet maintain a good level of interest from the audience like The Godfather. Coppola deserves credit for this. The symbolism and messages that went into every scene also has to do with the directing not just the writing. The movie is so well edited and strung together that the only word that could come to my mind is perfection. The cinematography and music were perfect. The Godfather seems to have this mystique to it, it gives you the feeling you are watching something truly remarkable. The horse's head, the scene of Brando running with his groceries, the coffee shop scene, "I'll give him an offer he can't refuse" and countless other scenes and quotes from this movie have become a part of our culture. These scenes and lines have been recycled over and over again in comedies, commercials, etc. that it is impossible to avoid the greatness of The Godfather.
